don't know if you still think about this talk as well but I send it to everybody essentially the thesis of the talk is that so many people from marginalized
backgrounds and marginalized identities will end up doing a category of work on their teams called glue work um glue
work is all the tasks that fall in between uh things that are considered engineering tasks or technical tasks but
things that are still critical for the team to function as a as a cohesive unit so an example is like um it maybe you're
on a team and you recognize that nobody has written onboarding documentation um and the new new joiners are having a
hard time ramping up because no like nothing about this is written down so you might take it upon yourself to
develop an onboarding checklist or write some documentation or come up with a system where new joiners pair with with
somebody old and have a buddy system for the first few months or weeks of the the there um but a thing that happens very
often with glue work is that you don't get promoted for it in fact like glue work is easy to mentally anchor on
because um because so few people are doing it you often get really nice positive feedback about it which sounds
really nice but um it's easy to write a piece of feedback like Jai developed this onboarding program for new joiners
and it was so great and now you know like people are really happy on the team um but that's not the thing that people
get promoted for people get promoted for engaging with difficult te like technical challenges from doing
technical leadership and for doing things that are hard to write about and hard to give feedback about um so glue
work is one of those things that I am so conscious of for my own career and as a
manager now I'm conscious about I I pay attention to who's doing the glue work and if I see someone doing too much I

most technical most tech companies promote people for delivering on technical work um you can do a certain
